page.title: 18OBOLISK
page.content:
IN 1814 JOHN DROSIER, OF CURDS HALL, BEING A FRIEND OF LORD NELSON, HAD THE OBALISK BUILT TO MARK THE PEACE OF AMIEN WHEN THE FRENCH WERE BEATEN THE YEAR BEFORE WATERLOO. NELSON DIED IN 1805. THE OBOLISK IS NOW A GRADE 2 HISTORICAL MONUMENT AND IS CURRENTLY BEING REPAIRED.
LOCAL LEGEND HAS IT THAT THE OBOLISK WAS TO MARK THE MEETING PLACE OF LORD NELSON, WHO STAYED AT CURDS HALL, AND LADY HAMILTON, WHO STAYED AT DUBHAM LODGE, WHERE THE TWO BOUNDARIES MET.
CURDS HALL WAS PULLED DOWN AFTER THE SECOND WORLD WAR AS IT WAS IN A STATE OF DISREPAIR.
